Can somebody help me? What does detained mean?﻿

+Jack Curtis It means that you are not free to leave, or in other words if 
you do try to leave the cop will fuck you up/take you to jail. Generally, 
the law recognizes 3 forms of interactions between the public and cops; 
consensual (you are free to leave at any time), detainment (you are not 
free to leave and the cop can't remove you from the immediate area), and 
arrest (you are not free to leave and you will be taken to jail).


For a detention, also called an investigative detention along with other 
names, to be lawful in any state in the US, the cop must have reasonable 
articulable suspicion of a crime either being committed, is about to be 
committed, or has been committed. This comes from the Terry v Ohio ruling. 
Also, from the Delaware v Prouse ruling, cops can't just detain you just 
because they want to ID you. Also, in I think every state, you only have to 
give state issued ID when being detained for committing a traffic 
infraction and generally the "stop and ID laws" only require verbally 
giving your name, DOB, and/or address and even then only upon arrest.


In short, this cop illegally detained the guy for either filming, or 
standing on public property, both of which are constitutionally protected 
activities which arguably means the cop was committing a felony color of 
law abuse under title 18 chapter 13 laws although cops are almost never 
held responsible for breaking those laws.

Who you are and what you're doing do not matter if you are within the 
reasonable distance--8 to 10 feet at least--from the scene. Identification 
is not necessary. They cannot force you to identify because you're not part 
of the initial reason they are on call in the first place. Checking ID is a 
scare tactic to make you feel as if you're now under investigation; coupled 
with the fear of police harassment, possible retaliations, and/or bogus 
charges. I would say, as a former journalist, either invest in a high-power 
zoom lens and tripod combo so that you can film more clearly from a 
distance, or write out/shorthand the laws on filming in a notepad, that 
fits in your pocket or small bag, and unless you cannot help it, do not go 
alone to film the police--if they get you alone, then they've got you, your 
footage, and there's more of a chance they will tamper with it unless you 
have someone you can hand over your footage to as well as have them film 
their own angle. You shouldn't feel bad if they (and I'm not saying they 
did) made you feel afraid; that's a fear instilled in everyone for 
years--not to fight back or disappoint a police officer, and do everything 
he/she says even if it's against the law. Even down to being in public 
schooling, two things they always teach you is to never ever under any 
circumstances fight back, and fear all forms of authority especially the 
police because they can punish you and take away your freedom.

Keep going sir, and don't give up even if it gets tough.﻿

This is pure bullshit.  The guy has zero obligation to even HAVE an ID, let 
alone show one.  It doesn't matter if the cop doesn't know or wants to know 
who the guy is or what he is doing, so long as there is no suspicion of 
crime being committed by the guy.  You can record whatever you like in 
spaces open to the public.  PLUS, the cop can't trespass you from public 
property, OR from private property, if the owner/manager of the private 
property hasn't demanded that the person leave.  It is complete horseshit. 
 The guy could have told the cop to go fuck himself, and there is nothing

Guys.. just to tell a cop to go fuck theirselves is not the way to beat 
them at their own game. But you have to know at least these 2 Supreme Court 
cases in this video.  First is to know that a cop is legally allowed to lie 
(Fraizer v. Cupp) and this one did lie when he said a public side walk was 
not public sidewalk.  Second Supreme Court case to know and be able to cite 
is Brown v. Texas. Which states that, in order for an officer to be able to 
legally demand your I.D, he MUST have a reasonable suspicion that you have 
committed OR are about to commit a crime. If he can not answer this 
question, "what crime do you suspect me of officer?" when asked by you, 
then that officer does not have a leg to stand on. That is when you refuse 
to answer any further questions and request that a supervisor come to the 
scene.  One last thing, police will often demand an I.D. by saying a person 
was acting suspicious.  But remember,  suspicious behavior is NOT 
"reasonable suspicion".﻿

Never show ID unless the officer can articulate a suspicion of a crime. Ask 
if you're being detained, just like you did, and if the answer is "yes", 
then ask for what crime. If the officer can't give you one, or the officer 
insists, request a road supervisor and let the officer know you'll be 
remaining silent until your attorney is present. There is not such thing as 
only being charged with failure to ID. There must always be an accompanying 
charge. In most states (if not all) it's illegal to just stop and ask for 
someone's papers. Win. ﻿

Technically the cop didn't do anything he wasn't "aloud" to do. The police 
and talk to ANYONE they encounter. We've got to remember that cops can 
legally lie to us and will. That cop just came up with a lie on the spot 
and the guy complied after going back and forth a few times. We have to 
generally assume everything they tell us is a lie. If we know what they can 
and can't do then we can assume everything they're telling us is to try to 
scare us or intimidate us. They're not really breaking a law even if they 
get hostile or rude with you and threaten beatings,Etc. Even IF you filed a 
complaint about that with the Department he MIGHT get a minor disciplinary 
infraction for being unprofessional or something. That's only if the file 
doesn't fall in the trash first. That's why it's so important to record ALL 
of our police interactions. If they do commit a criminal act they MIGHT be 
charged. Most important, don't fold even if they rough you up a little bit 
or a lot. Pain is only temporary, pride, dignity, principle, justice, 
morals, shame, and honor are absolute and forever. Plus you've got yourself 
a great case to get compensation for the encounter. We can't ever resist 
them, they will treat you very unfairly to try and get you to tell on 
yourself or implicate you in something. I try to just go with the flow. I 
try to perceive them as I would any other stranger that would confront me 
with a gun to a certain extent. I would describe them as thugs with rules 
they don't have to follow and can circumnavigate. Through trial and error 
I've come to understand that I am truly in control of ANY police encounter. 
Generally cops, in my experience, get very upset when you ask them 
questions ESPECIALLY if they've already answered it. Then they proceed to 
ask us the stupidest questions that they know the answer to, I.E. "What's 
your address??" While examining your drivers license. It's a double 
standard and unfair but what can you do? Certain confrontations and 
altercation in life are unavoidable and we've got to be able to properly 
react. They're generally very manipulative and feel like we owe them 
something. It's a game they're playing with our lives. It's our jobs to 
know they're game and come together as a society and beat them. If they 
didn't get what they wanted 90% of the time I would generally assume that 
they'd decline sweating it over time because of how much time and energy 
they'd have to put into I.D.'ing people they aren't required to if they 
know it's going to be a run around and a waste of time. I look at it like 
this, I don't owe a stranger an explanation for anything. Same with police. 
I'd rather be doing something else than having strangers explain themselves 
to me. Same with police. :)﻿

NO right to ask you for ID, and you have EVERY right not to give it to him. 
This is just another case of police intimidation and harassment. ﻿

You shouldn't have given him your ID. In fact, if you're just walking 
around, do not carry your ID with you. They have no right to detain or 
search you if you are not suspected of a crime. They also have no right to 
ask for your ID. They need probable cause, and carrying a camera while 
filming is not probable cause, nor is wearing your hat on backwards or 
having a tattoo.﻿
